Technical Assistance Report
 
 
Project Number: 52183-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2018 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Strengthening Education in the Pacific Region 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ODFL  –  open, distance, and flexible learning 
  PACREF  –  Pacific Regional Education Framework 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  Stephen Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  Carmela Locsin, Pacific Department (PARD) 
Director  Emma Veve, Urban, Social Development and Public Management 
Division, PARD 
   
Team leader  Chimi Thonden, Senior Education Specialist, PARD 
Team members  Leah Ann Castro, Operations Assistant, PARD 
  Lady Diane Kuizon, Operations Assistant, PARD 
  Ronald Mark G. Omana, Associate Project Analyst 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 10102018162413520357 Generated Date: 12-Nov-2018 14:47:00 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will (i) support Pacific developing 
member countries (DMCs) in addressing the perennial challenges in improving the quality of 
education through enhanced regionalism and mutually beneficial partnerships with regional 
institutions focused on the education priorities articulated in the Pacific Regional Education 
Framework (PACREF), 2019–2022;1 (ii) develop and expand access to a regional repository 
platform and learning management platform for open, distance, and flexible learning (ODFL); and 
(iii) support small assessments, studies, and exchanges to expand knowledge development and 
program development in the region. 
 
2.  This TA is aligned with the operational priorities of the Strategy 2030 of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) on addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities; ADB’s 
Education by 2020: A Sector Operations Plan, which recognizes the need to emphasize the 
strengthening of quality, inclusiveness, and relevant skills at all levels of education, while using 
new and innovative models of service delivery and financing; the Pacific Approach, 2016–2020 
strategic framework on supporting education and skills training to develop human capacity; and 
ADB’s Regional Operations Business Plan, 2019-2021.2 The TA contributes to Sustainable 
Development Goal 4 on ensuring inclusive and equitable quality education and promoting lifelong 
learning opportunities for all.3 It also supports a differentiated approach for small island developing 
states. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Weak student learning outcomes. While Pacific DMCs have made significant progress 
toward universal access to primary education, student learning outcomes remain poor. Results of 
the 2015 Pacific Islands Literacy and Numeracy Assessment show modest improvements, but 
greater effort is needed to strengthen learning as a foundational capacity that prepares young 
people for further education and work. The proportion of Pacific students at or above the expected 
proficiency level in numeracy is 86% for year 4 and 68% for year 6, which suggests improvement 
over the 2012 baseline of 74% for year 4 and 56%, for year 6. 4  However, the  2015 assessment 
showed no overall increase for literacy over the 2012 baseline; the proportion of students at or 
above the expected proficiency level was 46% for both year 4 and year 6 students compared with 
43.29% for year 4 and 48.39 for year 6% (footnote 4). 
 
4.  Constraints. Despite an emphasis on quality improvement strategies in many DMCs, 
improving the quality of education remains a challenge. Several constraints that impact quality 
include  economic, geographic,  and  political  constraints;  high  staff turnover;  coordination  of 
complimentary activities; capacity and accountability constraints on teachers and education 
managers;  data  collection  and  analysis  constraints;  social  constraints,  including  gender 
                                                
1  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  2014.  Technical  Assistance  for  Sector  and  Thematic  Analyses  in  Policy 
Development. Manila. The PACREF was approved at the Forum Education Ministers’ Meeting in Nauru in May 2018 
and was supported by ADB with grant financing from the Global Partnership for Education. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila; ADB. 2010. Education by 2020: A Sector Operations Plan. Manila; and ADB. 2017. Pacific Approach, 2016–
2020. Manila. ADB. 2018. Regional Operations Business Plan: Pacific, 2019–2021. Manila. ADB’s vice-president for 
operations 2 approved the TA concept paper on 9 October 2018, in accordance with ADB. 2018. Staff Instruction on 
Business Processes for Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance. Manila. 
3  United Nations. Sustainable Development Goal 4: Ensure Inclusive and Equitable Quality Education and Promote 
Lifelong Learning Opportunities for All. https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/sdg4. 
4  Education Quality and Assessment Program, Pacific Community. 2016. 2015 Pacific Islands Literacy and Numeracy 
Assessment (PILNA): Regional Report. Suva.

2 
inequality; and constraints relating to the language of instruction given that the Pacific is home to 
some of the greatest linguistic diversity in the world.5  In terms of gender inequality, female 
enrollment exceeds male enrollment in all Pacific countries, except for Papua New Guinea.  
Across the region, gender gaps are more likely to favor girls, particularly in Kiribati and Tuvalu, 
where the gender parity index for secondary school is 130.6  The 2015 administration of the Pacific 
Islands Literacy and Numeracy Assessment revealed that on average year 6 boys performed at 
a similar level to year 4 girls across the region in literacy (footnote 4). 
 
5.  Opportunities. Several factors have contributed to progress against these challenges, 
including commitment by governments to development goals; partnerships at all levels, including 
those between DMCs and development partners; regional cooperation through high-level forums 
and  regional  institutions;  increasing  demand  for  a  qualified  workforce;  integrated  national 
education planning and budgeting; school-based improvement initiatives; curriculum reform; and 
national policies for early childhood (footnote 5). Technology is increasingly viewed as an 
important facilitator to strengthening education delivery in the region. 
 
6.  Pacific-based solutions. Pacific DMCs face challenges related to their remoteness, 
dispersion, and small economies, which make them vulnerable to climate change risks and 
shocks.  Leveraging  economies  of  scale  to  create  and  share  Pacific solutions  can  provide 
significant and accelerated opportunities to improve the quality of education in the region. 
Strengthened regional mechanisms that encourage coordination and collaboration among Pacific 
regional institutions during planning and implementation are essential to ensure that limited 
financial resources are deployed efficiently and effectively. At the 50th Annual Meeting of the ADB 
Board of Governors, Pacific governors requested more Pacific-based solutions, underlining the 
importance of learning between DMCs, and the use of Pacific institutions and consultants. 
 
7.  Pacific  Regional  Education  Framework  support  for  regionalism.  The  PACREF 
(footnote 1) outlines the region’s shared priorities for education and training for 2019–2022, while 
also responding appropriately to global and regional demands. The four key policy areas identified 
by countries are (i) providing high-quality, relevant programs at all education levels; (ii) meeting 
learners’ needs through a broad range of programs and delivery modalities; (iii) achieving the full 
potential of learners at all education levels, from early childhood education to skills development; 
and (iv) supporting and empowering the teaching profession through opportunities for continuous 
professional learning, shared understanding, and accountability. The PACREF development 
began in 2016 under a participatory process involving a working group of the Pacific Heads of 
Education Systems, chaired by the Pacific Islands Forum Secretariat and funded by Global 
Partnership for Education with ADB as the grant agent. It ensures continued Pacific country 
ownership. Development partners will pool and coordinate funding under the framework to 
support a group of identified regional institutions in coordinating delivery of agreed priority regional 
goods and services under the framework. 
 
8.  Technology as a facilitator to achieving education goals. Access to quality and 
relevant learning content for the Pacific region is a longstanding issue. Progress has been made—
development partners such as ADB and New Zealand have pilot-testing e-learning resources— 
and the potential usefulness of a regional platform to better promote ODFL and a learning 
management platform is clear. 7 ADB has experience in Samoa, where it supported English, math, 
                                                
5  United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. 2015. Pacific Education for All 2015 Review. Paris. 
6  ADB. 2016. Gender Statistics: The Pacific and Timor-Leste. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2018. ICT for Better Education in the Pacific. Manila.

3 
and science e-learning resources at the secondary level.8 The Government of New Zealand is 
supporting a pilot program for science e-learning resources for year 11 in four Pacific DMCs. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: inclusive and equitable quality education 
ensured and lifelong learning opportunities for all promoted (footnote 3). The TA will have the 
following outcome: regional capacity to improve education outcomes in the Pacific enhanced.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Pacific Regional Education Framework implementation supported. The 
TA will fund the PACREF implementation plan for phase 1 (2019–2022).10 It will finance identified 
regional institutions that are delivering priority goods and services deemed essential to Pacific 
educational systems. The approach builds regional institutional capacity while also strengthening 
coordination and collaboration across countries receiving services. The TA provides a vehicle for 
expanding PACREF support beyond ADB’s own resources as cofinancing becomes available. A 
strong monitoring, evaluation, and learning component including sex-disaggregated data will be 
tied to the PACREF to ensure ongoing research and learning in designing education activities 
that improve gender equality in completion rates, learning outcomes, school-to-work transitions, 
and access to quality jobs. In addition, learning between DMCs will be emphasized, based on the 
request of Pacific DMCs. The PACREF outlines key policy objectives, goals, and intended 
outcomes and priority strategies that were determined by the Pacific Heads of Education Systems 
small working group and approved by the Pacific Islands Forum Education Ministers’ Meeting in 
May 2018. The four key policy areas identified are (i) quality and relevance, (ii) learning pathways, 
(iii) student outcomes and well-being, and (iv) the teaching profession. Key outcomes and 
strategies are outlined in the PACREF, and an implementation plan details the regional institutions 
responsible for specific activity areas. 
 
11.  Output  2:  Regional  repository  and  learning  management  platform  for  open, 
distance, and flexible learning established. In light of the small economies of Pacific DMCs, it 
is strategic to establish a regional center to develop e-learning resources and provide curatorial 
services with appropriate human resources and technical facilities in the Pacific (footnote 6). The 
TA will support contextualized teaching and learning resources for the Pacific, including adapting 
open education resources to the Pacific. It will support a regional center to develop, collect, and 
coordinate the interchange of e-resources between Pacific countries, and will be organized 
regionally to leverage economies of scale and support national e-learning resource repositories. 
The TA will support a strategic opportunity for ADB and New Zealand to collaborate on scaling up 
ODFL regionally. The initial focus for the regional repository will be on developing e-resources for 
primary and secondary education learning, particularly literacy but also math, sciences, with a 
focus on supporting girls to pursue science and math, and interdisciplinary areas relevant to the 
Pacific context. The repository will allow for country-level customization and will be demand-
driven. The TA will build on key regional institutions, including the University of the South Pacific’s 
School of Education for its ability to influence teacher education regionally, and its Centre for 
                                                
8  ADB. 2007. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Asian Development 
Fund Grant to the Independent State of Samoa for the SchoolNet and Community Access Project. Manila. 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
10 After phase 1, the PACREF will have two more phases, spanning 12 years in total.

4 
Flexible Learning; and the Pacific Centre for Flexible and Open Learning for Development, which 
is supported by the Commonwealth of Learning. 
 
12.  Output  3:  Small  assessments,  studies,  and  exchanges  to  expand  knowledge 
development and program development supported. The TA will support assessments and 
studies to expand knowledge development and exchange within the region. Possible studies and 
assessments include country-focused implementation of priority education and skills development 
areas, gender, pre-feasibility work for pipeline education investments in Pacific DMCs, and 
thematic analyses outside the PACREF that warrant further understanding or lead to new 
investment opportunities. The TA will also support participants in regional or subregional events 
and training programs where this can expand the scope of ADB’s activities. 
 
13.  Through the outputs, the TA will contribute to enhanced regional capacity to improve 
education by supporting implementation of the PACREF and establishing a regional repository 
and learning management platform for open, distance and flexible learning.  The TA will provide 
cross-country support for capacity development and knowledge generation. It will also offer a 
platform for policy dialogue with countries to discuss critical needs for investment in education 
and to showcase ADB’s engagement in the sector. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 
2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA. The executing agency will be the Pacific Department of ADB, 
and implementing agencies will be the Forum of Education Ministries. The University of the South 
Pacific, as the Chair of the Council of Regional Organizations in the Pacific for human resource 
development, will serve as an implementing partner of the implementing agencies. The indicative 
implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  January 2019–December 2023 
Executing agency  ADB 
Implementing agencies  Forum of Education Ministries, with USP serving as an implementing 
partner of the implementing agencies 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Individual consultant selection  International experts  $500,000 
(international)  (20 person-months) 
Individual consultant selection  National experts (16  $250,000 
(national)  person-months) 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, TA = technical assistance, USP = University of the South Pacific. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

5 
16.  Consulting services. The TA will require international and national consulting services, 
including education specialists, e-learning specialists, gender specialists, technical and vocational 
education and training specialists, engineers, and other resource persons. Consulting services 
will use output-based or time-based contracts depending on the nature of services. The TA will 
engage individual consultants using TA funds. The TA team will prepare the detailed terms of 
reference at a later stage because the specific areas of expertise needed are not yet known. ADB 
will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time 
to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.11 
 
17.  ADB’s procurement. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended 
from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Education in the Pacific Region, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
                                                
11 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
